To tell you the truth, I only listened to the queen because she's the queen but I did not think about it because I felt the proper proposition had not been done, Aigbon said.

The arrogance of Aigbon was getting to the queen and it infuriated her, had it been that it was her son who wanted to marry his daughter, she would have caused a stir by putting him in a proper place.

He even excuded so much disregards for the throne simply because he was the father of the girl they had come for.
The King noted Aigbon's attitude. Aigbon, I have left palace business to be here, I would not like you to waste my time. My Son wants to marry your daughter; that makes her the queen when I pass on to join my ancestors, I want a response from you.

Yes, I recall that you were here but I am sorry, my memory is not too good. I truly do not remember what we discussed, Aigbon said.
It was obvious that the timber merchant was being mischevious and it irked the queen albeit silently.

We came in respect of my intention to marry your daughter and you asked us to come back today, you said you needed to think about it, Prince Edimo offered.
Aigbon smiled. Ah-ha! I recall that and I also said it was the father that those the position.

Kola is offered to welcome and it is accepted for being welcomed. Your words of welcome are enough kola to us, the King said.
Aigbon chuckled. People may say this Aigbon is a stingy man but it is only a thing of principle. I have made not giving kola in my house a way of life so as to wade off unnecessary vultures who only visit to fill their stomach, Aigbon said.
